translation.displayName: Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease with (acute) exacerbation

tr.td:
Basic Information
Additional information: Chief Complaint from Nursing Triage Note : Chief Complaint
2022-12-25 9:34 EDT Chief Complaint Cough and flu like symptoms .

History of Present Illness
The patient presents with an upper respiratory infection. The onset was 4 days ago. The course/duration of symptoms is fluctuating in intensity. The degree at present is moderate. The exacerbating factor is none. The relieving factor is none. Risk factors consist of hypertension and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. Prior episodes: frequent. Therapy today: over the counter medications. Associated symptoms: dry cough, nasal congestion and rhinorrhea.
not using albuterol inhaler
still smoking

INDICATION: Cough for four days.
TECHNIQUE: Frontal chest was obtained at 10:02 hours.
COMPARISON: 2022-08-05 XR CHEST 2V
FINDINGS:
Both lungs are clear. The heart and mediastinum are of normal size and contour. No
pleural effusion. No pneumothorax. No acute bony abnormality identified.
IMPRESSION:
No findings of an acute cardiopulmonary process. No change from prior.
Signed by Michael Reiser, MD

text.paragraph: No data available for this section
No data available for this section

Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease Exacerbation
Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is a long-term (chronic) condition that affects the lungs. COPD is a general term that can be used to describe many different lung problems that cause lung inflammation and limit airflow, including chronic bronchitis and emphysema. COPD exacerbations are episodes when breathing symptoms flare up, become much worse, and require extra treatment.
COPD exacerbations are usually caused by infections. Without treatment, COPD exacerbations can be severe and even life threatening. Frequent COPD exacerbations can cause further damage to the lungs.
What are the causes?
This condition may be caused by:
• Respiratory infections, including viral and bacterial infections.
• Exposure to smoke.
• Exposure to air pollution, chemical fumes, or dust.
• Things that can cause an allergic reaction (allergens).
• Not taking your usual COPD medicines as directed.
• Underlying medical problems, such as congestive heart failure or infections not involving the lungs.
In many cases, the cause of this condition is not known.
What increases the risk?
The following factors may make you more likely to develop this condition:
• Smoking cigarettes.
• Being an older adult.
• Having frequent prior COPD exacerbations.
What are the signs or symptoms?
Symptoms of this condition include:
• Increased coughing.
• Increased production of mucus from your lungs.
• Increased wheezing and shortness of breath.
• Rapid or labored breathing.
• Chest tightness.
• Less energy than usual.
• Sleep disruption from symptoms.
• Confusion
• Increased sleepiness.
Often, these symptoms happen or get worse even with the use of medicines.
How is this diagnosed?
This condition is diagnosed based on:
• Your medical history.
• A physical exam.
You may also have tests, including:
• A chest X-ray.
• Blood tests.
• Lung (pulmonary) function tests.
How is this treated?
Treatment for this condition depends on the severity and cause of the symptoms. You may need to be admitted to a hospital for treatment. Some of the treatments commonly used to treat COPD exacerbations are:
• Antibiotic medicines. These may be used for severe exacerbations caused by a lung infection, such as pneumonia.
• Bronchodilators. These are inhaled medicines that expand the air passages and allow increased airflow. They may make your breathing more comfortable.
• Steroid medicines. These act to reduce inflammation in the airways. They may be given with an inhaler, taken by mouth, or given through an IV tube inserted into one of your veins.
• Supplemental oxygen therapy.
• Airway clearing techniques, such as noninvasive ventilation (NIV) and positive expiratory pressure (PEP). These provide respiratory support through a mask or other noninvasive device. An example of this would be using a continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) machine to improve delivery of oxygen into your lungs.
Follow these instructions at home:
Medicines
• Take over-the-counter and prescription medicines only as told by your health care provider.
• It is important to use correct technique with inhaled medicines.
• If you were prescribed an antibiotic medicine or oral steroid, take it as told by your health care provider. Do not stop taking the medicine even if you start to feel better.
Lifestyle
• Do not use any products that contain nicotine or tobacco. These products include cigarettes, chewing tobacco, and vaping devices, such as e-cigarettes. If you need help quitting, ask your health care provider.
• Eat a healthy diet.
• Exercise regularly.
• Get enough sleep. Most adults need 7 or more hours per night.
• Avoid exposure to all substances that irritate the airway, especially tobacco smoke.
• Regularly wash your hands with soap and water for at least 20 seconds. If soap and water are not available, use hand sanitizer. This may help prevent you from getting infections.
• During flu season, avoid enclosed spaces that are crowded with people.
General instructions
• Drink enough fluid to keep your urine pale yellow, unless you have a medical condition that requires fluid restriction.
• Use a cool mist vaporizer. This humidifies the air and makes it easier for you to clear your chest when you cough.
• If you have a home nebulizer and oxygen, continue to use them as told by your health care provider.
• Keep all follow-up visits. This is important.
How is this prevented?
• Stay up-to-date on pneumococcal and flu (influenza) vaccines. A flu shot is recommended every year to help prevent exacerbations.
• Quitting smoking is very important in preventing COPD from getting worse and in preventing exacerbations from happening as often.
• Follow all instructions for pulmonary rehabilitation after a recent exacerbation. This can help prevent future exacerbations.
• Work with your health care provider to develop and follow an action plan. This tells you what steps to take when you experience certain symptoms.
Contact a health care provider if:
• You have a worsening of your regular COPD symptoms.
Get help right away if:
• You have worsening shortness of breath, even when resting.
• You have trouble talking.
• You have severe chest pain.
• You cough up blood.
• You have a fever.
• You have weakness, vomit repeatedly, or faint.
• You feel confused.
• You are not able to sleep because of your symptoms.
• You have trouble doing daily activities.
These symptoms may represent a serious problem that is an emergency. Do not wait to see if the symptoms will go away. Get medical help right away. Call your local emergency services (911 in the U.S.). Do not drive yourself to the hospital.
Summary
• COPD exacerbations are episodes when breathing symptoms become much worse and require extra treatment above your normal treatment.
• Exacerbations can be severe and even life threatening. Frequent COPD exacerbations can cause further damage to your lungs.
• COPD exacerbations are usually triggered by infections such as the flu, colds, and even pneumonia.
• Treatment for this condition depends on the severity and cause of the symptoms. You may need to be admitted to a hospital for treatment.
• Quitting smoking is very important to prevent COPD from getting worse and to prevent exacerbations from happening as often.
This information is not intended to replace advice given to you by your health care provider. Make sure you discuss any questions you have with your health care provider.
Document Revised: 2022-01-26 Document Reviewed: 2022-01-26
